                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that the expression is can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{(18+1)^7 + 17}{18+1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow (18+1)^6 + \frac{17}{19} \Rightarrow"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the remainder is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            A better way to explain this is to show that 1, 7, 21, 35, 35, 21, 7 are elements in the 7th row of the Pascal Triangle.

title: #18 Measure Your Calibre
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Positive reals "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"abc=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Find the infimum value of"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac {a^3}{(a-b)(a-c)} + \frac {b^3}{(b-c)(b-a)} + \frac {c^3}{(c-a)(c-b)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Other problems: "},{"type":"text","text":"Check your Calibre","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]}

title: 18 Pentagons!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/FgtS1DHMyH-capture.PNG?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A regular 18-gon is dissected into 18 pentagons, each of which is congruent to pentagon "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABCDE"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as shown. All sides of the pentagon have the same length."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Determine angles "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A, B, C, D, \text {and } E"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and What is their sum? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Bonus:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X, Y \text {and } Z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" collinear?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/R6f0Qdn8E4-capture.PNG?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
We notice at the center of the 18-gon, six pentagons are joined together by their angle that corresponds to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle A \implies \angle A= \frac{360^\circ}{6}=60^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since all the sides of the pentagon are equal, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle ABE"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is equilateral and quadrilateral "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BCDE"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a rhombus."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an interior angle of the 18-gon, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle B= \angle ABC= 160^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle EBC=\angle ABC-\angle ABE= 160^\circ-60^\circ = 100^\circ."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"which implies "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle D= \angle CDE= \angle EBC= 100^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle C= \angle BED=180^\circ -\angle EBC= 180^\circ - 100^\circ =80^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle E= \angle AED = \angle AEB+\angle BED= 60^\circ+ 80^\circ=140^\circ."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To summarize: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}\angle A= 60^\circ,\color{#20A900} \angle B= 160^\circ,\color{#3D99F6} \angle C=80^\circ,\color{#69047E}\angle D= 100^\circ,\color{#EC7300}\angle E=140^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \implies S= 60^\circ+160^\circ+80^\circ+100^\circ+140^\circ=\boxed{540^\circ}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the Bonus question, the answer is yes they are collinear but requires to prove "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle XYZ= 180^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". (I will provide the proof later)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The question has two parts, the first part is what is the measure of each angle, definitely their sum is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"540"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", maybe l should change the problem a bit.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Actually, you can solve this faster using the fact that all convex pentagons have the sum of their angles as 540 degrees, but kudos to you for rather elegantly solving for all of the individual angles of the pentagon.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            That's true but I was asking for the measure of each angle first, then their sum should be 540 as an extra verification.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The sum of the internal angles of any n-gon is 180(n-2). Thus for any pentagon the answer is 540.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
